An Operator Splitting View of Federated Learning

Saber Malekmohammadi1,2 , Kiarash Shaloudegi211footnotemark: 1, Zeou Hu 1,2, Yaoliang Yu1
University of Waterloo, Canada1
{saber.malekmohammadi, zeou.hu, yaoliang.yu}@uwaterloo.ca
Huawei Noah’s Ark Lab, Montreal, Canada2
kiarash.shaloudegi@huawei.com These authors contributed equally to this work
Abstract

Over the past few years, the federated learning (FL) community has witnessed a proliferation of new FL algorithms. However, our understating of the theory of FL is still fragmented, and a thorough, formal comparison of these algorithms remains elusive. Motivated by this gap, we show that many of the existing FL algorithms can be understood from an operator splitting point of view. This unification allows us to compare different algorithms with ease, to refine previous convergence results and to uncover new algorithmic variants. In particular, our analysis reveals the vital role played by the step size in FL algorithms. The unification also leads to a streamlined and economic way to accelerate FL algorithms, without incurring any communication overhead. We perform numerical experiments on both convex and nonconvex models to validate our findings.

1 Introduction

The accompanying (moderate) computational power of modern smart devices such as phones, watches, home appliances, cars, etc., and the enormous data accumulated from their interconnected ecosystem have fostered new opportunities and challenges to train/tailor modern deep models. Federated learning (FL), as a result, has recently emerged as a massively distributed framework that enables training a shared or personalized model without infringing user privacy. Tremendous progress has been made since the seminal work of [1], including algorithmic innovations [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], convergence analysis [9, 10, 11, 12, 13], personalization [14, 15, 16, 17, 18], privacy protection [19, 20], model robustness [21, 22, 23, 24], fairness [25, 26, 27], standardization [28, 29], applications [30], just to name a few. We refer to the excellent surveys [31, 32, 33] and the references therein for the current state of affairs in FL.

The main goal of this work is to take a closer examination of some of the most popular FL algorithms, including FedAvg [1], FedProx [2], and FedSplit [5], by connecting them with the well-established theory of operator splitting in optimization. In particular, we show that FedAvg corresponds to forward-backward splitting and we demonstrate a trade-off in its step size and number of local epochs, while a similar phenomenon has also been observed in [10, 5, 12, 34]. FedProx, on the other hand, belongs to backward-backward splitting, or equivalently, forward-backward splitting on a related but regularized problem, which has been somewhat overlooked in the literature. Interestingly, our results reveal that the recent personalized model in [15] is exactly the problem that FedProx aims to solve. Moreover, we show that when the step size in FedProx diminishes (sublinearly fast), then it actually solves the original problem, which is contrary to the observation in [5] where the step size is fixed and confirms again the importance of step size in FL.

For FedSplit, corresponding to Peaceman-Rachford splitting [35, 36], we show that its convergence (in theory) heavily hinges on the strong convexity of the objective and hence might be less stable for nonconvex problems.

Inspecting FL through the lens of operator splitting also allows us to immediately uncover new FL algorithms, by adapting existing splitting algorithms. Indeed, we show that Douglas-Rachford splitting [37, 36] (more precisely the method of partial inverse [38]) yields a (slightly) slower but more stable variant of FedSplit, while at the same time shares a close connection to FedProx: the latter basically freezes the update of a dual variable in the former. We also propose FedRP by combining the reflector in FedSplit and the projection (averaing) in FedAvg and FedProx, and extend an algorithm of [39]. We improve the convergence analysis of FedRP and empirically demonstrate its competitiveness with other FL algorithms. We believe these results are just the tip of the ice-berg and much more progress can now be expected: the marriage between FL and operator splitting simply opens a range of new possibilities to be explored.

Our holistic view of FL algorithms suggests a very natural unification, building on which we show that the aforementioned algorithms reduce to different parameter settings in a grand scheme. We believe this is an important step towards standardizing FL from an algorithmic point of view, in addition to standard datasets, models and evaluation protocols as already articulated in [28, 29]. Our unification also allows one to compare and implement different FL algorithms with ease, and more importantly to accelerate them in a streamlined and economic fashion. Indeed, for the first time we show that Anderson-acceleration [40, 41], originally proposed for nonlinear fixed-point iteration, can be adapted to accelerate existing FL algorithms and we provide practical implementations that do not incur any communication overhead. We perform experiments on both convex and nonconvex models to validate our findings, and compare the above-mentioned FL algorithms on an equal footing.

We proceed in §2 with some background introduction. Our main contributions are presented in §3, where we connect FL with operator splitting, shed new insights on existing algorithms, suggest new algorithmic variants and refine convergence analysis, and in §4, where we present a unification of current algorithms and propose strategies for further acceleration. We conclude in §5 with some future directions. Due to space limit, all proofs are deferred to Appendix C.

2 Background

In this section we recall the federated learning (FL) framework of [1]. We consider m𝑚m users (edge devices), where the i𝑖i-th user aims at minimizing a function fi:ℝd→ℝ,i=1,…,m:subscript𝑓𝑖formulae-sequence→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ𝑖1…𝑚f_{i}:\mathds{R}^{d}\to\mathds{R},i=1,\ldots,m, defined on a shared model parameter 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathds{R}^{d}. Typically, each user function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} depends on the respective user’s local (private) data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. The main goal in FL is to collectively and efficiently optimize individual objectives {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} in a decentralized, privacy-preserving and low-communication way.

Following [1], many existing FL algorithms fall into the natural formulation that optimizes the (arithmetic) average performance:

3 FL as operator splitting

Following [5], in this section we interpret existing FL algorithms (FedAvg, FedProx, FedSplit) from the operator splitting point of view. We reveal the importance of the step size, obtain new convergence guarantees, and uncover some new and accelerated algorithmic variants.

3.1 FedAvg as forward-backward splitting

The FedAvg algorithm of [1] is essentially a k𝑘k-step version of the forward-backward splitting approach of [42]:

𝗐t+1←𝖯H​𝖦𝖿,kηt​𝗐t,where𝖦𝖿,kηt:=𝖦𝖿ηt∘𝖦𝖿ηt∘⋯∘𝖦𝖿ηt⏟k​ times ,formulae-sequence←subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿𝑘subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡whereassignsuperscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿𝑘subscript𝜂𝑡subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡⋯superscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡𝑘 times \displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f},k}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f},k}^{\eta_{t}}:=\underbrace{\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\circ\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\circ\cdots\circ\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}}_{k\mbox{ times }}, (9)

where we perform k𝑘k steps of (forward) gradient updates w.r.t. 𝖿𝖿\mathsf{f} followed by 1 (backward) proximal update w.r.t. H𝐻H. To improve efficiency, [1] replace 𝖦𝖿ηtsuperscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}} with 𝖦^𝖿ηtsuperscriptsubscript^𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡\mathsf{\hat{G}}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}} where the (sub)gradient is approximated on a minibatch of training data and 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H} with 𝖯^Hsubscript^𝖯𝐻\mathsf{\hat{P}}_{H} where we only average over a chosen subset It⊆[m]:={1,…,m}subscript𝐼𝑡delimited-[]𝑚assign1…𝑚I_{t}\subseteq[m]:=\{1,\ldots,m\} of users. Note that the forward step 𝖦𝖿,kηtsuperscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿𝑘subscript𝜂𝑡\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f},k}^{\eta_{t}} is performed in parallel at the user side while the backward step 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H} is performed at the server side.

The number of local steps k𝑘k turns out to be a key factor: Setting k=1𝑘1k=1 reduces to the usual (stochastic) forward-backward algorithm and enjoys the well-known convergence guarantees. On the other hand, setting k=∞𝑘k=\infty (and assuming convergence on each local function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}) amounts to (repeatedly) averaging the chosen minimizers of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}’s, and eventually converges to the average of minimizers of all m𝑚m user functions. In general, the performance of the fixed point solution of FedAvg appears to have a dependency on the number of local steps k𝑘k and the step size η𝜂\eta. Let us illustrate this with quadratic functions fi​(𝐰)=12​‖Ai​𝐰−𝐛i‖22subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰12superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐴𝑖𝐰subscript𝐛𝑖22f_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\tfrac{1}{2}\|A_{i}\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{b}_{i}\|_{2}^{2} and non-adaptive step size ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta, where we obtain the fixed-point 𝐰FedAvg∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰FedAvg𝑘\mathbf{w}_{\texttt{FedAvg}}^{*}(k) of FedAvg in closed-form [5]:

𝐰FedAvg∗​(k)=(∑i=1m1k​∑j=0k−1Ai⊤​Ai​(I−η​Ai⊤​Ai)j)−1​(∑i=1m1k​∑j=0k−1(I−η​Ai⊤​Ai)j​Ai⊤​𝐛i).superscriptsubscript𝐰FedAvg𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖superscript𝐼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘1superscript𝐼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐛𝑖\displaystyle\textstyle\mathbf{w}_{\texttt{FedAvg}}^{*}(k)=\big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}A_{i}^{\top}A_{i}(I\!-\!\eta A_{i}^{\top}A_{i})^{j}\big{)}^{\!-1}\big{(}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}(I\!-\!\eta A_{i}^{\top}A_{i})^{j}A_{i}^{\top}\mathbf{b}_{i}\big{)}. (10)

For small η𝜂\eta we may apply Taylor expansion and ignore the higher order terms:

1k​∑j=0k−1(I−η​Ai⊤​Ai)j≈1k​∑j=0k−1(I−j​η​Ai⊤​Ai)=I−η​(k−1)2​Ai⊤​Ai.1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘1superscript𝐼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑘1𝐼𝑗𝜂superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝐼𝜂𝑘12superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑖topsubscript𝐴𝑖\displaystyle\textstyle\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}(I-\eta A_{i}^{\top}A_{i})^{j}\approx\frac{1}{k}\sum_{j=0}^{k-1}(I-j\eta A_{i}^{\top}A_{i})=I-\tfrac{\eta(k-1)}{2}A_{i}^{\top}A_{i}. (11)

Thus, we observe that the fixed point 𝐰FedAvg∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝐰FedAvg𝑘\mathbf{w}_{\texttt{FedAvg}}^{*}(k) of FedAvg depends on η​(k−1)𝜂𝑘1\eta(k-1), up to higher order terms. In particular, when k=1𝑘1k=1, the fixed point does not depend on η𝜂\eta (as long as it is small enough to guarantee convergence), but for k>1𝑘1k>1, the solution that FedAvg converges to does depend on η𝜂\eta. Moreover, the final performance is almost completely determined by η​(k−1)𝜂𝑘1\eta(k-1) in this quadratic setting when η𝜂\eta is small, as we verify in experiments, see Figure 2 left (details on generating Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} and 𝐛isubscript𝐛𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i} can be found in section A.1).

Figure 7 in the appendix further illustrates this trade-off where larger local epochs k𝑘k and learning rate η𝜂\eta leads to faster convergence (in terms of communication rounds) during the early stages, at the cost of a worse final solution. Similar results are also reported in e.g. [10, 5, 12, 34]. In Figure 2, we run FedAvg in (9) on least squares, logistic regression and a nonconvex CNN on the MNIST dataset [43]. The experiments are run with pre-determined numbers of communication rounds and different configurations of local epochs k𝑘k and learning rates η𝜂\eta. (Complete details of our experimental setup are given in Appendix A.222All nonconvex experimental results in this paper are averaged over 4 runs with different random seeds.) We examine the dependencies of FedAvg’s final performance regarding k𝑘k and η𝜂\eta. We can conclude that, in general, smaller local epochs and learning rates gives better final solutions (assuming sufficient communication rounds to ensure convergence). Moreover, for least squares and logistic regression, the product η​(k−1)𝜂𝑘1\eta(k-1) we derived in (11) almost completely determines the final performance, when k𝑘k and η𝜂\eta are within a proper range. For the nonconvex CNN (Fig 2, right), especially with limited communications, the approximation in (11) is too crude to be indicative.

3.2 FedProx as backward-backward splitting

The recent FedProx algorithm [2] replaces the gradient update in FedAvg with a proximal update:

𝗐t+1=𝖯H​𝖯𝖿ηt​𝗐t,subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}, (12)

where as before we may use a minibatch to approximate 𝖯𝖿ηsuperscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} or select a subset of users to approximate 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H}. Written in this way, it is clear that FedProx is an instantiation of the backward-backward splitting algorithm of [44, 45]. In fact, this algorithm traces back to the early works of e.g. [46, 47, 48], sometimes under the name of the Barycenter method. It was also rediscovered by [49, 50] in the ML community under a somewhat different motivation. [5] pointed out that FedProx does not solve the original problem (1). While technically correct, their conclusion did not take many other subtleties into account, which we explain next.

Following [51], we first note that, with a constant step size ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta, FedProx is actually equivalent as FedAvg but applied to a “regularized” problem:

min𝗐∈H𝖿~​(𝗐),where𝖿~​(𝗐):=⟨𝟏,𝖬𝐟η​(𝗐)⟩, and ​𝖬𝐟η​(𝗐)=(𝖬f1η​(𝐰1),…,𝖬fmη​(𝐰m)).formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝗐𝐻~𝖿𝗐where~𝖿𝗐1superscriptsubscript𝖬𝐟𝜂𝗐 and superscriptsubscript𝖬𝐟𝜂𝗐superscriptsubscript𝖬subscript𝑓1𝜂subscript𝐰1…superscriptsubscript𝖬subscript𝑓𝑚𝜂subscript𝐰𝑚\displaystyle\min_{\mathsf{w}\in H}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w}),\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w}):=\left\langle\mathbf{1},\mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})\right\rangle,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mbox{ and }\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\big{(}\mathsf{M}_{f_{1}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{1}),\ldots,\mathsf{M}_{f_{m}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\big{)}. (13)

Interestingly, [15] proposed exactly (13) for the purpose of personalization, which we now realize is automatically achieved if we apply FedProx to the original formulation (1). Indeed, ∇𝖬𝐟η​(𝗐)=[𝗐−𝖯𝐟η​(𝗐)]/η∇superscriptsubscript𝖬𝐟𝜂𝗐delimited-[]𝗐superscriptsubscript𝖯𝐟𝜂𝗐𝜂\nabla\mathsf{M}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=[\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{P}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})]/\eta hence 𝖦f~η​(𝗐)=𝗐−η​∇𝖿~​(𝗐)=𝖯𝐟η​(𝗐)=(𝖯f1η​(𝐰1),…,𝖯fmη​(𝐰m))superscriptsubscript𝖦~𝑓𝜂𝗐𝗐𝜂∇~𝖿𝗐superscriptsubscript𝖯𝐟𝜂𝗐superscriptsubscript𝖯subscript𝑓1𝜂subscript𝐰1…superscriptsubscript𝖯subscript𝑓𝑚𝜂subscript𝐰𝑚\mathsf{G}_{\tilde{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\mathsf{w}-\eta\nabla\tilde{\mathsf{f}}(\mathsf{w})=\mathsf{P}_{\mathbf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w})=\big{(}\mathsf{P}_{f_{1}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{1}),\ldots,\mathsf{P}_{f_{m}}^{\eta}(\mathbf{w}_{m})\big{)}. This simple observation turns out to be crucial in understanding FedProx.

Indeed, a significant challenge in FL is user heterogeneity (a.k.a. non-iid distribution of data), where the individual user functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} may be very different (due to distinct user-specific data). But, we note that333These results are classic and well-known, see e.g. [52]. as η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0, 𝖬fη→f→superscriptsubscript𝖬𝑓𝜂𝑓\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to f (pointwise or uniformly if f𝑓f is Lipschitz) while 𝖬fη→min⁡f→superscriptsubscript𝖬𝑓𝜂𝑓\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to\min f as η→∞→𝜂\eta\to\infty. In other words, a larger η𝜂\eta in (13) “smoothens” heterogeneity in the sense that the functions 𝖬fiηsuperscriptsubscript𝖬subscript𝑓𝑖𝜂\mathsf{M}_{f_{i}}^{\eta} tend to have similar minimizers (while the minimum values may still differ). We are thus motivated to understand the convergence behaviour of FedProx, for small and large η𝜂\eta, corresponding to the original problem (1) and the smoothened problem, respectively. In fact, we can even adjust η𝜂\eta dynamically. Below, for simplicity, we assume full gradient (i.e. large batch size) although extensions to stochastic gradient are possible.

Theorem 1.

Assuming each user participates indefinitely, the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} is bounded from below (i.e. lim inftηt>0subscriptlimit-infimum𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡0\liminf_{t}\eta_{t}>0), the user functions {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} are convex, and homogeneous in the sense that they have a common minimizer, i.e. 𝖥:=⋂iargmin𝐰ifi​(𝐰i)≠∅assign𝖥subscript𝑖subscriptargminsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖\mathsf{F}:=\bigcap_{i}\operatorname*{argmin}_{\mathbf{w}_{i}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{i})\neq\emptyset, then the iterates of FedProx converge to a point in 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F}, which is a correct solution of (1).

The homogeneity assumption might seem strong since it challenges the necessity of FL in the first place. However, we point out that (a) as a simplified limiting case it does provide insight on when user functions have close minimizers (i.e. homogeneous); (b) by using a large step size η𝜂\eta FedProx effectively homogenizes the users and its convergence thus follows444The consequence of this must of course be further investigated; see [15] and [2].; (c) modern deep architectures are typically over-parameterized so that achieving null training loss on each user is not uncommon. However, FL is still relevant even in this case since it selects a model that works for every user and hence provides some regularizing effect; (d) even when the homogeneity assumption fails, 𝖯𝖿ηtsuperscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}} still converges to a point that is in some sense closest to H𝐻H [51].

The next result removes the homogeneity assumption by simply letting step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} diminish:

Theorem 2 ([44, 45]).

Assuming each user participates in every round, the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} satisfies ∑tηt=∞subscript𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡\sum_{t}\eta_{t}=\infty and ∑tηt2<∞subscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2\sum_{t}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty, and the functions {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} are convex, then the averaged iterates 𝗐¯t:=∑s=1tηs​𝗐s∑s=1tηsassignsubscript¯𝗐𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑡subscript𝜂𝑠subscript𝗐𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑡subscript𝜂𝑠\bar{\mathsf{w}}_{t}:=\tfrac{\sum_{s=1}^{t}\eta_{s}\mathsf{w}_{s}}{\sum_{s=1}^{t}\eta_{s}} of FedProx converge to a correct solution of the original problem (1).

In Appendix C, we give examples to show the tightness of the step size condition in Theorem 2. We emphasize that 𝗐¯tsubscript¯𝗐𝑡\bar{\mathsf{w}}_{t} converges to a solution of the original problem (1), not the regularized problem (13). The subtlety is that we must let the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} approach 0 reasonably slowly, a possibility that was not discussed in [5] where they always fixed the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} to a constant η𝜂\eta. Theorem 2 also makes intuitive sense, as ηt→0→subscript𝜂𝑡0\eta_{t}\to 0 slowly, we are effectively tracking the solution of the regularized problem (13) which itself tends to the original problem (1): recall that 𝖬fη→f→superscriptsubscript𝖬𝑓𝜂𝑓\mathsf{M}_{f}^{\eta}\to f as η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0.

Even the ergodic averaging step in Theorem 2 can be omitted in some cases:

Theorem 3 ([45]).

Under the same assumptions as in Theorem 2, if 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is strongly convex or the solution set of (1) has nonempty interior, then the vanilla iterates 𝗐tsubscript𝗐𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedProx also converge.

We remark that convergence is in fact linear for the second case. Nevertheless, the above two conditions are perhaps not easy to satisfy or verify in most applications. Thus, in practice, we recommend the ergodic averaging in Theorem 2 since it does not create additional overhead (if implemented incrementally) and in our experiments it does not slow down the algorithm noticeably.

There is in fact a quantitative relationship between the original problem (1) and the regularized problem (13), even in the absence of convexity:

Theorem 4 ([50]).

Suppose each fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is Misubscript𝑀𝑖M_{i}-Lipschitz continuous (and possibly nonconvex), then

∀𝗐,f​(𝗐)−f~​(𝗐)≤∑iλi​η​Mi22.for-all𝗐𝑓𝗐~𝑓𝗐subscript𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑖22\displaystyle\textstyle\forall\mathsf{w},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ f(\mathsf{w})-\tilde{f}(\mathsf{w})\leq\sum_{i}\lambda_{i}\tfrac{\eta M_{i}^{2}}{2}. (14)

Thus, for a small step size η𝜂\eta, FedProx, aiming to minimize the regularized function 𝖿~~𝖿\tilde{\mathsf{f}} is not quantitatively different from FedAvg that aims at minimizing 𝖿𝖿\mathsf{f}. This again reveals the fundamental importance of step size in FL. We remark that, following the ideas in [50], we may remove the need of ergodic averaging for FedProx if the functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are “definable” (which most, if not all, functions used in practice are). We omit the technical complication here since the potential gain does not appear to be practically significant.

In Figure 3, we show the effect of step size η𝜂\eta on the convergence of FedProx, and compare the results with that of FedAvg on both convex and nonconvex models. We run FedProx with both fixed and diminishing step sizes. In the experiments with diminishing step sizes, we have set the initial value of η𝜂\eta (i.e. η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}) to larger values - compared to the constant η𝜂\eta values - to ensure that η𝜂\eta does not get very small after the first few rounds. From the convex experiments (Fig 3, left and middle), one can see that FedProx with a fixed learning rate converges fast (in a few hundred rounds) to a suboptimal solution. In contrast, FedProx with diminishing η𝜂\eta converges slower, but to better quality solutions. It is interesting to note that only when the conditions of Theorem 2 are satisfied (i.e. η𝜂\eta diminishes neither too fast nor too slow), FedProx converges to a correct solution of the original problem (1), e.g. see the results for ηt∝1/tproportional-tosubscript𝜂𝑡1𝑡\eta_{t}\propto 1/t which satisfies both conditions in Theorem 2. Surprisingly, for the nonconvex setting (Figure 3, right), the best results are achieved with larger learning rates. A similar observation about FedAvg in nonconvex settings was reported in [1, Fig. 5 & 6]. 555Note that the results of FedAvg and FedProx for η=100𝜂100\eta=100 and 100/log⁡(t)100𝑡100/\log(t) overlap with each other. Moreover, from the results on both convex and nonconvex models, one can see that ergodic averaging does not affect the convergence rate of FedProx noticeably.

3.3 FedSplit as Peaceman-Rachford splitting

[5] introduced the FedSplit algorithm recently:

𝗐t+1=𝖱H​𝖱𝖿ηt​𝗐t,subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝖱𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}, (15)

which is essentially an instantiation of the Peaceman-Rachford splitting algorithm [35, 36]. As shown by [36], FedSplit converges to a correct solution of (1) if 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is strictly convex, and the convergence rate is linear if 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is strongly convex and smooth (and η𝜂\eta is small). [5] also studied the convergence behaviour of FedSplit when the reflector 𝖱𝖿ηsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} is computed approximately. However, we note that convergence behaviour of FedSplit is not known or widely studied for nonconvex problems. In particular, we have the following surprising result:

Theorem 5.

If the reflector 𝖱fηsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝑓𝜂\mathsf{R}_{f}^{\eta} is a (strict) contraction, then f𝑓f must be strongly convex.

The converse is true if f𝑓f is also smooth and η𝜂\eta is small [36, 53]. Therefore, for non-strongly convex or nonconvex problems, we cannot expect FedSplit to converge linearly (if it converges at all).

3.4 FedPi as Douglas-Rachford splitting

A popular alternative to the Peaceman-Rachford splitting is the Douglas-Rachford splitting [37, 36], which, to our best knowledge, has not been applied to the FL setting. The resulting update, which we call FedPi, can be written succinctly as:

𝗐t+1=𝗐t+𝖱H​𝖱𝖿ηt​𝗐t2,subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝖱𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡2\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1}=\tfrac{\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}}{2}, (16)

i.e. we simply average the current iterate and that of FedSplit evenly. Strictly speaking, the above algorithm is a special case of the Douglas-Rachford splitting and was rediscovered by [54] under the name of partial inverse (hence our name FedPi). The moderate averaging step in (16) makes FedPi much more stable:

Theorem 6 ([54, 36]).

Assuming each user participates in every round, the step size ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta is constant, and the functions {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} are convex, then the vanilla iterates 𝗐tsubscript𝗐𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedPi converge to a correct solution of the original problem (1).

Compared to FedSplit, FedPi imposes less stringent condition on fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i}. However, when fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is indeed strongly convex and smooth, as already noted by [36], FedPi will be slower than FedSplit by a factor close to 22\sqrt{2} (assuming the constant step size is set appropriately for both). More importantly, it may be easier to analyze FedPi on nonconvex functions, as recently demonstrated in [55, 56].

Interestingly, FedPi also has close ties to FedProx. Indeed, this is best seen by expanding the concise formula in (16) and introducing a “dual variable” 𝗎𝗎\mathsf{u} on the server side666The acute readers may have recognized here the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). Indeed, the equivalence of ADMM, Douglas-Rachford and partial inverse (under our FL setting) has long been known [[, e.g. ]]Gabay83,EcksteinBertsekas92.:

𝗓t+1subscript𝗓𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{z}_{t+1} ←𝖯𝖿η​(𝗐t+𝗎t)←absentsuperscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂subscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}(\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t}) (17)
𝗐t+1subscript𝗐𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} ←𝖯H​(𝗓t+1−𝗎t)←absentsubscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗓𝑡1subscript𝗎𝑡\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}{\color[rgb]{.5,.5,.5}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{.5,.5,.5}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{.5}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{.5}-\mathsf{u}_{t}}) (18)
𝗎t+1subscript𝗎𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{u}_{t+1} ←𝗎t+𝗐t+1−𝗓t+1.←absentsubscript𝗎𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝗓𝑡1\displaystyle\leftarrow\mathsf{u}_{t}+\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{z}_{t+1}. (19)

From the last two updates (18) and (19) it is clear that 𝗎t+1subscript𝗎𝑡1\mathsf{u}_{t+1} is always in H⟂superscript𝐻perpendicular-toH^{\perp}. Thus, after performing a change of variable 𝗏t:=𝗐t+𝗎tassignsubscript𝗏𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡\mathsf{v}_{t}:=\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t} and exploiting the linearity of 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H}, we obtain exactly FedPi:

𝗏t+1=𝗎t+2​𝗐t+1−𝗓t+1=𝗏t−𝖯H​𝗏t+2​𝖯H​𝖯𝖿η​𝗏t−𝖯𝖿η​𝗏t=𝗏t+𝖱H​𝖱𝖿η​𝗏t2.subscript𝗏𝑡1subscript𝗎𝑡2subscript𝗐𝑡1subscript𝗓𝑡1subscript𝗏𝑡subscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗏𝑡2subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂subscript𝗏𝑡superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂subscript𝗏𝑡subscript𝗏𝑡subscript𝖱𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂subscript𝗏𝑡2\displaystyle\mathsf{v}_{t+1}=\mathsf{u}_{t}+2\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{z}_{t+1}=\mathsf{v}_{t}-\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{v}_{t}+2\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}-\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}=\tfrac{\mathsf{v}_{t}+\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{v}_{t}}{2}. (20)

Comparing (12) and (17)-(18) it is clear that FedProx corresponds to fixing the dual variable 𝗎𝗎\mathsf{u} to the constant 𝟎0\mathbf{0} in FedPi. We remark that step (17) is done at the users’ side while steps (18) and (19) are implemented at the server side. There is no communication overhead either, as the server need only communicate the sum 𝗐t+𝗎tsubscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t}+\mathsf{u}_{t} to the respective users while the users need only communicate their 𝐳t,isubscript𝐳𝑡𝑖\mathbf{z}_{t,i} to the server. The dual variable 𝗎𝗎\mathsf{u} is kept entirely at the server’s expense.

Let us point out another subtle difference that may prove useful in FL: FedAvg and FedProx are inherently “synchronous” algorithms, in the sense that all participating users start from a common, averaged model at the beginning of each communication round. In contrast, the local models 𝗓tsubscript𝗓𝑡\mathsf{z}_{t} in FedPi may be different from each other, where we “correct” the common, average model 𝗐tsubscript𝗐𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t} with user-specific dual variables 𝗎tsubscript𝗎𝑡\mathsf{u}_{t}. This opens the possibility to personalization by designating the dual variable 𝗎𝗎\mathsf{u} in user-specific ways.

Lastly, we remark that in FedProx we need the step size ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} to diminish in order to converge to a solution of the original problem (1) whereas FedPi achieves the same with a constant step size η𝜂\eta, although at the cost of doubling the memory cost at the server side.

3.5 FedRP as Reflection-Projection splitting

Examining the updates in (9), (12) and (15), we are naturally led to the following further variants (that have not been tried in FL to the best of our knowledge):

𝗐t+1subscript𝗐𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =𝖱H​𝖦𝖿ηt​𝗐tabsentsubscript𝖱𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖦𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡\displaystyle=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{G}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t} (21)
𝗐t+1subscript𝗐𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =𝖱H​𝖯𝖿ηt​𝗐tabsentsubscript𝖱𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡\displaystyle=\mathsf{R}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t} (22)
FedRP:𝗐t+1\displaystyle\mbox{{FedRP}}:\qquad\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =𝖯H​𝖱𝖿ηt​𝗐t.absentsubscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡\displaystyle=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}\mathsf{w}_{t}. (23)

Interestingly, the last variant in (23), which we call FedRP, has been studied by [39] under the assumption that 𝖿=ι𝖪𝖿subscript𝜄𝖪\mathsf{f}=\iota_{\mathsf{K}} is an indicator function of an obtuse777Recall that a convex cone 𝖪𝖪\mathsf{K} is obtuse iff its dual cone 𝖪∗:={𝐰∗:⟨𝐰,𝐰∗⟩≥0}assignsuperscript𝖪conditional-setsuperscript𝐰𝐰superscript𝐰0\mathsf{K}^{*}:=\{\mathbf{w}^{*}:\left\langle\mathbf{w},\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\rangle\geq 0\} is contained in itself. convex cone 𝖪𝖪\mathsf{K}. We prove the following result for FedRP:

Theorem 7.

Let each user participate in every round and the functions {fi}subscript𝑓𝑖\{f_{i}\} be convex. If the step size ηt≡ηsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜂\eta_{t}\equiv\eta is constant, then any fixed point of FedRP is a solution of the regularized problem (13). If the reflector 𝖱𝖿ηsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta} is idempotent (i.e. 𝖱𝖿η​𝖱𝖿η=𝖱𝖿ηsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}=\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}) and the users are homogeneous, then the vanilla iterates 𝗐tsubscript𝗐𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t} of FedRP converge.

It follows easily from a result in [39] that a convex cone is obtuse iff its reflector is idempotent, and hence Theorem 7 strictly extends their result. We remark that Theorem 7 does not apply to the variants (21) and (22) since the reflector 𝖱Hsubscript𝖱𝐻\mathsf{R}_{H} is not idempotent (recall H𝐻H is defined in (4)). Of course, we can prove (linear) convergence of both variants (21) and (22) if 𝖿𝖿\mathsf{f} is strongly convex. We omit the formal statement and proof since strong convexity does not appear to be easily satisfiable in practice.

In Figure 4, we compare the performance of different splitting algorithms and how they respond to different degrees of user heterogeneity. We use least squares and a CNN model on MNIST for the convex and noconvex experiments, respectively. The details of the experimental setup are described in Section A.1. For the convex setting, as expected, FedSplit, FedPi, and FedAvg with k=1𝑘1k=1 achieve the smallest optimality gaps. The performance of all the algorithms deteriorates as users’ data become more heterogeneous (see Section A.1). For the nonconvex setting, the best results can be achieved by FedRP and FedAvg with a big k𝑘k. It is noteworthy that in the nonconvex setting, the performance of FedAvg with k=1𝑘1k=1 is significantly worse than that with k=100𝑘100k=100.

4 Unification, implementation and acceleration

The operator splitting view of FL not only allows us to compare and understand the many existing FL algorithms but also opens the door for unifying and accelerating them. In this section we first introduce a grand scheme that unifies all aforementioned FL algorithms. Then, we provide two implementation variants that can accommodate different hardware and network constraints. Lastly, we explain how to adapt Anderson acceleration [40] to the unified FL algorithm, with almost no computation or communication overhead.

Unification.

We introduce the following grand scheme:

𝗓t+1subscript𝗓𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{z}_{t+1} =(1−αt)​𝗎t+αt​𝖯𝖿ηt​(𝗎t)absent1subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡\displaystyle=(1-\alpha_{t})\mathsf{u}_{t}+\alpha_{t}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}(\mathsf{u}_{t}) (24)
𝗐t+1subscript𝗐𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{w}_{t+1} =(1−βt)​𝗓t+1+βt​𝖯H​(𝗓t+1)absent1subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝗓𝑡1subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗓𝑡1\displaystyle=(1-\beta_{t})\mathsf{z}_{t+1}+\beta_{t}\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) (25)
𝗎t+1subscript𝗎𝑡1\displaystyle\mathsf{u}_{t+1} =(1−γt)​𝗎t+γt​𝗐t+1.absent1subscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝗎𝑡subscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡1\displaystyle=(1-\gamma_{t})\mathsf{u}_{t}+\gamma_{t}\mathsf{w}_{t+1}. (26)

Table 1 confirms that the FL algorithms discussed in Section 3 are all special cases of this unifying scheme, which not only provides new (adaptive) variants but also clearly reveals the similarities and differences between seemingly different algorithms. It may thus be possible to transfer progress on one algorithm to the others and vice versa. We studied the effect of α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta and γ𝛾\gamma and found that γ𝛾\gamma mostly affects the convergence speed: the closer γ𝛾\gamma is to 1, the faster the convergence is, while α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta mostly determine the final optimality gap: the closer they are both to 2 (as in FedSplit and FedPi), the considerably smaller the final optimality gap is. However, setting only one of them close to 2 only has a minor effect on optimality gap or convergence speed.

Implementation.

Interestingly, we also have two implementation possibilities:

  • •

    decentralized: In this variant, all updates in (24)-(26) are computed and stored locally at each user while the server only acts as a bridge for synchronization: it receives 𝐳t+1,isubscript𝐳𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{z}_{t+1,i} from the i𝑖i-th user and returns the (same) averaged model 𝖯H​(𝗓t+1)subscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗓𝑡1\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) to all users. In a network where users communicate directly with each other, we may then dispense the server and become fully decentralized.

  • •

    centralized: In this variant, the i𝑖i-th user only stores 𝐮t,isubscript𝐮𝑡𝑖\mathbf{u}_{t,i} and is responsible for computing and communicating 𝖯fiηt​(𝐮t,i)superscriptsubscript𝖯subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐮𝑡𝑖\mathsf{P}_{f_{i}}^{\eta_{t}}(\mathbf{u}_{t,i}) to the server. In return, the server performs the rest of (24)-(26) and then sends (different) 𝐮t+1,isubscript𝐮𝑡1𝑖\mathbf{u}_{t+1,i} back to the i𝑖i-th user.

The two variants are of course mathematically equivalent in their basic form. However, as we see below, they lead to different acceleration techniques and we may prefer one over the other depending on the hardware and network constraints.

Acceleration.

Let us abstract the grand scheme (24)-(26) as the map 𝗎t+1=𝖳𝗎tsubscript𝗎𝑡1subscript𝖳𝗎𝑡\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}, where 𝖳𝖳\mathsf{T} is nonexpansive if 𝖿𝖿\mathsf{f} is convex and αt,βt∈[0,2],γt∈[0,1]formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡02subscript𝛾𝑡01\alpha_{t},\beta_{t}\in[0,2],\gamma_{t}\in[0,1]. Following [41], we may then apply the Anderson type-II acceleration to furthur improve convergence. Let U=[𝗎t−τ,…,𝗎t]𝑈subscript𝗎𝑡𝜏…subscript𝗎𝑡U=[\mathsf{u}_{t-\tau},\ldots,\mathsf{u}_{t}] be given along with T=[𝖳𝗎t−τ,…,𝖳𝗎t]𝑇subscript𝖳𝗎𝑡𝜏…subscript𝖳𝗎𝑡T=[\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t-\tau},\ldots,\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}]. We solve the following simple least-squares problem:

𝝅∗=argmin𝝅⊤​𝟏=1{‖(U−T)​𝝅‖22}=G†​𝟏𝟏⊤​G†​𝟏,whereG=(U−T)⊤​(U−T).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝝅subscriptargminsuperscript𝝅top11superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑈𝑇𝝅22superscript𝐺†1superscript1topsuperscript𝐺†1where𝐺superscript𝑈𝑇top𝑈𝑇\displaystyle\bm{\pi}^{*}=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\bm{\pi}^{\top}\mathbf{1}=1}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \{\|(U-T)\bm{\pi}\|_{2}^{2}\}=\tfrac{G^{\dagger}\mathbf{1}}{\mathbf{1}^{\top}G^{\dagger}\mathbf{1}},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathrm{where}\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ G=(U-T)^{\top}(U-T). (27)

(For simplicity we do not require 𝝅𝝅\bm{\pi} to be nonnegative.) Then, we update 𝗎t+1=T​𝝅∗subscript𝗎𝑡1𝑇superscript𝝅\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=T\bm{\pi}^{*}. Clearly, when τ=0𝜏0\tau=0, (trivially) π∗=1superscript𝜋1\pi^{*}=1 and we reduce to 𝗎t+1=𝖳𝗎tsubscript𝗎𝑡1subscript𝖳𝗎𝑡\mathsf{u}_{t+1}=\mathsf{T}\mathsf{u}_{t}. With a larger memory size τ𝜏\tau, we may significantly improve convergence. Importantly, all heavy lifting (computation and storage) is done at the server side and we do not increase communication at all. We note that the same acceleration can also be applied on each user for computing 𝖯𝖿ηtsuperscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿subscript𝜂𝑡\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta_{t}}, if the users can afford the memory cost.

We have already seen how different variants (e.g. FedAvg, FedProx, FedSplit, FedPi, FedRP) compare to each other in §3. We performed further experiments to illustrate their behaviour under Anderson acceleration. (See Appendix A for details on our experimental setup.) As can be observed in Figure 5, Anderson acceleration helps FL algorithms converge considerably faster, all without incurring any overhead. For the convex models (least squares and logistic regression), our implementation of Anderson-acceleration speeds up all of the algorithms, especially FedAvg, FedProx and FedRP. However, for the nonconvex CNN model, it is beneficial only for FedAvg, FedProx and FedPi, while applying it to FedRP and FedSplit makes them unstable. It is noteworthy that we already know FedProx and FedPi are more stable than FedRP and FedSplit, respectively, and hence it makes intuitive sense that acceleration improves the two more stable algorithms. Another important point we wish to point out is that our acceleration method does not affect the quality of the algorithms’ final solutions, but rather it just accelerates their convergence.

5 Conclusions

We have connected FL with the established theory of operator splitting, revealed new insights on existing algorithms and suggested new algorithmic variants and analysis. Our unified view makes it easy to understand, compare, implement and accelerate different FL algorithms in a streamlined and standardized fashion. Our experiments demonstrate some interesting differences in the convex and nonconvex settings, and in the early and late communication rounds. In the future we plan to study the effect of stochasticity and extend our analysis to nonconvex functions. While our initial experiments confirmed the potential of Anderson-acceleration for FL, further work is required to formalize its effect in theory (such as [58]) and to understand its relation with other momentum methods in FL.

Having generated the design matrices Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i} and sampled the labels 𝐛isubscript𝐛𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i} for all users, we find the maximum likelihood estimate of 𝐰0subscript𝐰0\mathbf{w}_{0} by solving the following convex program, which has a solution 𝐰∗subscript𝐰\mathbf{w}_{*}:

min𝐰∈ℝd⁡F​(𝐰):=∑i=1mfi​(𝐰)=∑i=1m∑j=1nilog⁡(1+e−bi​j​𝐚i​j⊤​𝐰)+‖𝐰‖222​m​ni.assignsubscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑖1superscript𝑒subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑖𝑗top𝐰superscriptsubscriptnorm𝐰222𝑚subscript𝑛𝑖\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathds{R}^{d}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ F(\mathbf{w}):=\sum_{i=1}^{m}f_{i}(\mathbf{w})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{i}}\log(1+e^{-b_{ij}\mathbf{a}_{ij}^{\top}\mathbf{w}})+\frac{\|\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2}}{2mn_{i}}.

Following [5], we set

m=10,d=100,ni=1000.formulae-sequence𝑚10formulae-sequence𝑑100subscript𝑛𝑖1000\displaystyle\centering m=10,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ d=100,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ n_{i}=1000.\@add@centering

Data heterogeneity measure:

We adopt the data heterogeneity measure of [11], and quantify the amount of heterogeneity in users’ data for the least squares and logistic regression problems by

H:=1m​∑i=1m‖∇fi​(𝐰∗)‖22,assign𝐻1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰22\displaystyle H:=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\parallel\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{*})\parallel_{2}^{2},

where 𝐰∗subscript𝐰\mathbf{w}_{*} is a minimizer of the original problem (1). When users’ data is homogeneous, all the local functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} have the same minimizer of 𝐰∗subscript𝐰\mathbf{w}_{*} and H=0𝐻0H=0. In general, the more heterogeneous the users’ data is, the larger H𝐻H becomes.

Other parameters:

Throughout the experiments, we use local learning rate η=10−5𝜂superscript105\eta=10^{-5} for least squares, and η=10−2𝜂superscript102\eta=10^{-2} for logistic regression, and run FedAvg with k=5𝑘5k=5 for both least squares and logistic regression, unless otherwise specified. In Figure 5, FedAvg is run with k=2𝑘2k=2.

A.2 Experimental setup: MNIST datasets

We consider a distributed setting with 202020 users. In order to create a non-i.i.d. dataset, we follow a similar procedure as in [1]: first we split the data from each class into several shards. Then, each user is randomly assigned a number of shards of data. For example, in Figure 4 to guarantees that no user receives data from more than 666 classes, we split each class of MNIST into 121212 shards (i.e., a total of 120120120 shards for the whole dataset), and each user is randomly assigned 666 shards of data. By considering 202020 users, this procedure guarantees that no user receives data from more than 666 classes and the data distribution of each user is different from each other. The local datasets are balanced–all users have the same amount of training samples. The local data is split into train, validation, and test sets with percentage of 808080%, 101010%, and 101010%, respectively. In this way, each user has 240024002400 data points for training, 300300300 for test, and 300300300 for validation. We use a simple 2-layer CNN model with ReLU activation, the detail of which can be found in Table 2. To update the local models at each user using its local data, unless otherwise is stated, we apply gradient descent with η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 for FedAvg, and gradient descent with k=100𝑘100k=100 and η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 for proximal update in the splitting algorithms.

A.3 Experimental setup: CIFAR-10 dataset

We consider a distributed setting with 101010 users, and use a sub-sampled CIFAR-10 dataset, which is 20%percent2020\% of the training set. In order to create a non-i.i.d. dataset, we follow a similar procedure as in [1]: first we sort all data points according to their classes. Then, they are split into 100100100 shards, and each user is randomly assigned 101010 shards of data. The local data is split into train, validation, and test sets with percentage of 808080%, 101010%, and 101010%, respectively. In this way, each user has 800800800 data points for training, 100100100 for test, and 100100100 for validation. We use a 2-layer CNN model on the dataset, , the detail of which can be found in Table 3. To update the local models at each user using its local data, we apply stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with local batch size B=20𝐵20B=20 and local learning rate η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1. All users participate in each communication round.

Appendix B Full experiments

In this section we provide more experimental results that are deferred from the main paper.

B.1 FedRP experiments to supplement Figure 2

In Figure 6, we show the effect of step size η𝜂\eta on the convergence of FedRP on least squares and logistic regression. We run FedRP with both fixed and diminishing step sizes. In the experiments with diminishing step sizes, we set the initial value of η𝜂\eta (i.e. η0subscript𝜂0\eta_{0}) to larger values–compared to the constant η𝜂\eta values–to ensure that η𝜂\eta does not get very small after the first few rounds. From the figure, one can see that FedRP with a fixed learning rate converges faster in early stage but to a sub-optimal solution. In contrast, FedRP with diminishing η𝜂\eta converges slower early, but to better final solutions. It is interesting to note that the convergence behaviour of FedRP is similar to that of FedProx and when the conditions of Theorem 2 are satisfied, FedRP converges to a correct solution of the original problem (1), e.g. see the results for ηt∝1/tproportional-tosubscript𝜂𝑡1𝑡\eta_{t}\propto 1/t which satisfies both conditions in Theorem 2. Moreover, one can see that ergodic averaging hardly affects the convergence of FedRP in the following results.

B.2 Effect of changing k𝑘k or η𝜂\eta for FedAvg

In Figure 7, we observe a trade-off between faster (early) convergence and better final solution when varying local epochs k𝑘k or learning rate η𝜂\eta, in least squares and logistic regression experiments. When η𝜂\eta is fixed, larger local epochs k𝑘k leads to faster convergence (in terms of communication rounds) during the early stages, at the cost of a worse final solution. When local epochs k𝑘k is fixed, same trade-off holds true for increasing η𝜂\eta.

In Figure 8, contrary to what we observe in the previous convex experiments where fixed learning rate with less local epochs leads to a better final solution at the expense of slower convergence, we do not see similar trade-offs in this nonconvex setting, (at least) given the computation we can afford. This is probably because the solution we get is still in early stage due to the combined complexity of CNN and CIFAR-10 dataset, compared to the relatively simple least squares and logistic regression we had before.

B.3 Effect of user sampling

The grand scheme introduced in (24)-(26) assumes that all users participate in each communication round–full user participation; however, this might not be always the case. So, we modify the grand scheme to investigate the effect of user participation. The modified version, which is based on the centralized implementation of FL algorithms (explained in section 4), is given in Algorithm 1. The simulation results for least squares and logistic regression are shown in Figure 9. From the results it can be observed that, with partial user participation, none of the aforementioned algorithms converge to the correct solution, especially FedAvg with k=1𝑘1k=1. Also, FedSplit becomes unstable when user participation is low (p=0.5𝑝0.5p=0.5), while other algorithms e.g. FedPi remain stable.

B.4 Effect of using mini-batch gradient descent locally

Figure 10 shows the results when each user uses mini-batch gradient descent to update its model for different splitting algorithms. As in the grand scheme (24)-(26), we assume full user participation. Algorithm 2 summarizes the implementation details. As can be observed in the convex setting experiments, with mini-batch gradient descent used locally, none of the aforementioned algorithms converge to the correct solution. Furthermore, convergence speed of the algorithms decreases compared to when users use standard gradient descent. Also, FedAvg, even with k=1𝑘1k=1, does not outperform the other splitting algorithms, and FedSplit and FedPi converge to better solutions. On the other hand, in the nonconvex setting, FedAvg with k=100𝑘100k=100 achieves better solutions compared to the other algorithms.

B.5 Results with error bars: Figure 1, Left

To avoid clutter, we did not present the error bars in Figure 2 but report them here. The y𝑦y-axis represents the training loss {f​(𝐰FedAvg∗)}𝑓superscriptsubscript𝐰FedAvg\{f(\mathbf{w}_{\texttt{FedAvg}}^{*})\} of (approximate) fixed-point solutions of FedAvg for different learning rates η𝜂\eta and local epochs k𝑘k, and the shaded area illustrates the maximum and minimum over 4 different runs.

B.6 Results with error bars: Figure 2, Left

Figure 12 shows the effect of step size η𝜂\eta and averaging on FedProx for nonconvex CNN on MNIST, and the shaded area illustrates the maximum and minimum over 4 different runs. The deviation among different runs is quite small.

B.7 Results with error bars: Figure 3, Bottom

The following figures demonstrate the effect of data heterogeneity on the performance of different splitting methods for nonconvex CNN model, and the shaded area illustrates the maximum and minimum over 4 different runs.

B.8 Results with error bars: Figure 4, Left

Implementation details of Anderson acceleration for nonconvex CNN:

In practice, we found that applying the acceleration algorithm to 𝖯H​(𝗓t+1)subscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗓𝑡1\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}) in (25) rather than 𝗎t+1subscript𝗎𝑡1\mathsf{u}_{t+1} in (26) leads to a more stable algorithm. So, we applied acceleration to 𝖯H​(𝗓t+1)subscript𝖯𝐻subscript𝗓𝑡1\mathsf{P}_{H}(\mathsf{z}_{t+1}), and used the result to find 𝗎t+1subscript𝗎𝑡1\mathsf{u}_{t+1} and 𝗐t+1subscript𝗐𝑡1\mathsf{w}_{t+1} for the nonconvex model.

Figure 16 shows the effect of Anderson acceleration on the nonconvex CNN with memory size τ=10𝜏10\tau=10. FedRP and FedSplit are less stable and Anderson acceleration actually made them worse while FedAvg, FedProx and FedPi converge much faster with our implementation of Anderson acceleration. The deviation among 4 different runs is shown as the shaded area.

Appendix C Proofs

We first recall the following convenient result:

Lemma 1 ([59], [60, Theorem 5.36]).

Let {𝐰t}subscript𝐰𝑡\{\mathbf{w}_{t}\} and {𝐳t}subscript𝐳𝑡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\} be two sequences in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathds{R}^{d}, ∅≠𝖥⊆ℝd𝖥superscriptℝ𝑑\emptyset\neq\mathsf{F}\subseteq\mathds{R}^{d}, and Wk:=clconv(𝐰t:t≥k)W_{k}:=\mathop{\mathrm{cl}}\mathrm{conv}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t}:t\geq k\right). Suppose that

  1. 1.

    for all 𝐰∈𝖥𝐰𝖥\mathbf{w}\in\mathsf{F}, ‖𝐰t−𝐰‖22→p​(𝐰)<∞→superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑡𝐰22𝑝𝐰\|\mathbf{w}_{t}-\mathbf{w}\|_{2}^{2}\to p(\mathbf{w})<\infty;

  2. 2.

    for all k𝑘k, 𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍​(𝐳t,Wk)→0→𝖽𝗂𝗌𝗍subscript𝐳𝑡subscript𝑊𝑘0\mathsf{dist}(\mathbf{z}_{t},W_{k})\to 0 as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty.

Then, the sequence {𝐳t}subscript𝐳𝑡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\} has at most one limit point in 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F}. Therefore, if additionally

  1. 3.

    all limit points of {𝐳t}subscript𝐳𝑡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\} lie in 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F},

then the whole sequence {𝐳t}subscript𝐳𝑡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\} converges to a point in 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F}.

Below, we use well-known properties about firm nonexpansions and Fejér monotone sequences, see the excellent book [60] for background.

Proof.

The proof is a simplification and application of [61].

Consider all possible combinations of user participation, i.e. let ℐ:=2[m]∖∅assignℐsuperscript2delimited-[]𝑚\mathcal{I}:=2^{[m]}\setminus\emptyset be the power set of users [m]:={1,…,m}assigndelimited-[]𝑚1…𝑚[m]:=\{1,\ldots,m\}, with the empty set removed. For each I∈ℐ𝐼ℐI\in\mathcal{I}, define

Moreover, since we assume each fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} to be convex, the mapping 𝖳I,ηsubscript𝖳𝐼𝜂\mathsf{T}_{I,\eta} is firmly nonexpansive. In fact, 𝖳I,η=𝖯fIηsubscript𝖳𝐼𝜂superscriptsubscript𝖯subscript𝑓𝐼𝜂\mathsf{T}_{I,\eta}=\mathsf{P}_{f_{I}}^{\eta} for a so-called proximal average function fIsubscript𝑓𝐼f_{I} [60], and hence it follows from [62] that

Proof.

We simply verify Lemma 1. We remark that the step size condition is tight, as shown by the following simple example:

Proof.

To see the first claim, let 𝗐𝗐\mathsf{w} be a fixed point of FedRP, i.e.

𝗐=𝖯H​𝖱𝖿η​𝗐=𝖯H​(2​𝖯𝖿η​𝗐−𝗐)=2​𝖯H​𝖯𝖿η​𝗐−𝖯H​𝗐=2​𝖯H​𝖯𝖿η​𝗐−𝗐,𝗐subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂𝗐subscript𝖯𝐻2superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂𝗐𝗐2subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂𝗐subscript𝖯𝐻𝗐2subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂𝗐𝗐\displaystyle\mathsf{w}=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}=\mathsf{P}_{H}(2\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{w})=2\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{w}=2\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{w}, (53)

since 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H} is linear and 𝗐∈H𝗐𝐻\mathsf{w}\in H due to the projection. Thus, 𝗐=𝖯H​𝖯𝖿η​𝗐𝗐subscript𝖯𝐻superscriptsubscript𝖯𝖿𝜂𝗐\mathsf{w}=\mathsf{P}_{H}\mathsf{P}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}. In other words, the fixed points of FedRP are exactly those of FedProx, and the first claim then follows from [51], see the discussions in Section 3.2 and also [39, Lemma 7.1].

To prove the second claim, we first observe that {𝗐t}subscript𝗐𝑡\{\mathsf{w}_{t}\} is Fejér monotone w.r.t. 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F}, the solution set of the regularized problem (13). Indeed, for any 𝗐∈𝖥𝗐𝖥\mathsf{w}\in\mathsf{F}, using the firm nonexpansiveness of 𝖯Hsubscript𝖯𝐻\mathsf{P}_{H} we have

‖𝗐t+1−𝗐‖22+‖𝖱𝖿η​𝗐t−𝗐t+1−𝖱𝖿η​𝗐+𝗐‖22≤‖𝖱𝖿η​𝗐t−𝖱𝖿η​𝗐‖22≤‖𝗐t−𝗐‖22.superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝗐𝑡1𝗐22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂subscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂𝗐𝗐22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂subscript𝗐𝑡superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂𝗐22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝗐𝑡𝗐22\displaystyle\|\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{w}\|_{2}^{2}+\|\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}_{t}-\mathsf{w}_{t+1}-\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}+\mathsf{w}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}_{t}-\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|\mathsf{w}_{t}-\mathsf{w}\|_{2}^{2}. (54)

Summing and telescoping the above we know

𝖱𝖿η​𝗐t−𝗐t+1→𝖱𝖿η​𝗐−𝗐.→superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂subscript𝗐𝑡subscript𝗐𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂𝗐𝗐\displaystyle\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}_{t}-\mathsf{w}_{t+1}\to\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}-\mathsf{w}. (55)

Let 𝗐∞subscript𝗐\mathsf{w}_{\infty} be a limit point of {𝗐t}subscript𝗐𝑡\{\mathsf{w}_{t}\} (which exists since 𝗐tsubscript𝗐𝑡\mathsf{w}_{t} is bounded). When the users are homogeneous, we can choose 𝗐=𝖱𝖿η​𝗐𝗐superscriptsubscript𝖱𝖿𝜂𝗐\mathsf{w}=\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}^{\eta}\mathsf{w}. Therefore, 𝗐∞∈rge𝖱𝖿=Fix​𝖱𝖿subscript𝗐rgesubscript𝖱𝖿Fixsubscript𝖱𝖿\mathsf{w}_{\infty}\in\mathop{\mathrm{rge}}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}=\mathrm{Fix}\mathsf{R}_{\mathsf{f}}. Since 𝐰∞∈Hsubscript𝐰𝐻\mathbf{w}_{\infty}\in H by definition, 𝐰∞∈𝖥subscript𝐰𝖥\mathbf{w}_{\infty}\in\mathsf{F}. Applying Lemma 1 we conclude that the entire Fejér sequence {𝗐t}subscript𝗐𝑡\{\mathsf{w}_{t}\} converges to 𝐰∞∈𝖥subscript𝐰𝖥\mathbf{w}_{\infty}\in\mathsf{F}. ∎

As shown in [39], a (closed) convex cone is obtuse iff its reflector is idempotent. To give another example: the univariate, idempotent reflector 𝖱f​(w)=(w)+:=max⁡{w,0}subscript𝖱𝑓𝑤subscript𝑤assign𝑤0\mathsf{R}_{f}(w)=(w)_{+}:=\max\{w,0\} leads to

𝖯f​(w)=w+𝖱f​w2=w+(w)+2⟹f​(w)=12​(−w)+2.subscript𝖯𝑓𝑤𝑤subscript𝖱𝑓𝑤2𝑤subscript𝑤2𝑓𝑤12superscriptsubscript𝑤2\displaystyle\mathsf{P}_{f}(w)=\tfrac{w+\mathsf{R}_{f}w}{2}=\tfrac{w+(w)_{+}}{2}\implies f(w)=\tfrac{1}{2}(-w)_{+}^{2}. (56)

Interestingly, the epigraph of the above f𝑓f is a convex set but not a cone and yet its reflector is idempotent. Therefore, the idempotent condition introduced here is a strict generalization of [39].
